comment:
This isn't losing, but much more aggressive is 2. Bc4 or 2. Nf3. As it is,
your light-squared bishop is now hemmed in. Notice the bishop had 5 legal
moves prior to moving your pawn to d3; now it has only one.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5
comment:
?? Clearly a bad move by the computer. White will win with best play; I know
white didn't, so let's see what white could have done to collect the fullpoint.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2
comment:
An opening principle is: Don't move a piece
twice in the opening without good reason. Clearly move 4 was justified for the
free queen! However, the bishop has a good post already on e3. Why not either
Nc3 or Nbd2? Remember, when ahead a lot in material, trade pieces! Therefore,
white had nothing to fear by a potential BxN by black.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5
comment:
The first misstep. Always get developed
first, THEN attack. Therefore, Be2, O-O is called for first. Then white has
his choice of opening lines with d4 or attacking on the kingside with Qe1-g3,
Nh4-f5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4
comment:
A nice move! This denies black any
counterplay, and establishes a clamp on the key central square on d5.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3
comment:
Oops! If you must retreat, retreat TOWARD the center. Nc3 is called for.
In addition, if white's knight was on c3, white can advance d4 without having
to worry about his e4 pawn (since in that case, the knight would be protecting
it).

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4
comment:
This isn't right. Just get developed with Be2. Don't worry
about 15. ... g4, because Nh4, O-O and Nf5 is strong (notice how if you got
developed, your rook would partcipate).

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3
comment:
Why? Getting your bishop active is still mandatory. g3
followed by Bg2 or h3, and white would still be winning.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8
comment:
The computer misses a cheapo. White can win a free piece with Qxe4!
Notice black cannot take the white queen, because the f-pawn is pinned! It is
illegal for black to expose his king to check, so white gets a knight scott
free.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2
comment:
This hangs a piece. Kg2 was safe and strong...
black's f-pawn wasn't going anywhere. Besides, if white had to, he can sac
(sacrifice) his rook for pawn and knight, which is still better than losing
the bishop for the pawn.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5
comment: Instead, Qxf5+ Ke7 28. h4 would leave white in a strong position.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5 Nb4 28. Qb1
comment:
Too passive. Qf2! is natural and strong. Remember with your heavy pieces
(rooks & queens), have them double on an open column, or file. What might
happen is 28. Qf2 Ne4 29. Qf3 Ng5 30. Qg4 (threatening Rxg5, discovered check!)
Ke7 31. Raf1, getting nearly all white's pieces into the attack. The only
straggler is that knight at a3, but he can be rerouted by Nb1- c3.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5 Nb4 28. Qb1 Reg8 29. Nc2
comment: Not the best. 29. h4, followed by Qe4 and Raf1 would still be very strong.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5 Nb4 28. Qb1 Reg8 29. Nc2 Kxf5 30. Nd4+ Kf6 31. Qf5+ Ke7 32. Qe6+ Kf8
comment: ? A poor move by black. Simply 32. ... Nxe6 would force white to resign.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5 Nb4 28. Qb1 Reg8 29. Nc2 Kxf5 30. Nd4+ Kf6 31. Qf5+ Ke7 32. Qe6+ Kf8 33. Qc8+ Kg7 34. Qxc7+ Nf7 35. Ne6+
comment:
Instead, 25. Rf1! wins outright! That move
would threaten Qxf7#, so therefore black would have to play ...Rf8, but THEN
36. Ne6+ Kg6 37. Qe7 is lights out for black. There is this phrase among
tournament chess players, "Monkey see check, monkey do check". Don't be a
monkey! Only check if there's a concrete reason to do so.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5 Nb4 28. Qb1 Reg8 29. Nc2 Kxf5 30. Nd4+ Kf6 31. Qf5+ Ke7 32. Qe6+ Kf8 33. Qc8+ Kg7 34. Qxc7+ Nf7 35. Ne6+ Kg6 36. Qe7 Nc2 37. Rf1 Nxe3+ 38. Kg1 Nxf1 39. Kxf1 b6 40. g4 Re8 41. Qh4
comment:
This was the losing
move for white. To have a fighting chance, white had to play 41. Qd7 to
protect his knight.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. d3 Bc5 3. Be3 Qg5 4. Bxg5 h6 5. Be3 Bb4+ 6. Bd2 Bc5 7. Be3 Bxe3 8. fxe3 Nf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. Nc3 d6 11. Nb5 Kd8 12. Qd2 Be6 13. c4 a6 14. Na3 g5 15. d4 g4 16. d5 gxf3 17. dxe6 Nxe4 18. Qc2 f2+ 19. Ke2 f5 20. b3 Ke7 21. g3 Kxe6 22. Bh3 Rac8 23. Kf3 Ng5+ 24. Kxf2 Nxh3+ 25. Kg2 Ng5 26. Rhf1 Rce8 27. Rxf5 Nb4 28. Qb1 Reg8 29. Nc2 Kxf5 30. Nd4+ Kf6 31. Qf5+ Ke7 32. Qe6+ Kf8 33. Qc8+ Kg7 34. Qxc7+ Nf7 35. Ne6+ Kg6 36. Qe7 Nc2 37. Rf1 Nxe3+ 38. Kg1 Nxf1 39. Kxf1 b6 40. g4 Re8 41. Qh4 Rxe6 42. g5 Nxg5 43. Kf2 Rf8+ 44. Kg3 Rf4 45. Qxh6+ Kxh6 46. Kg2 Rg4+ 47. Kf2 Rf6+ 48. Ke2 Rg2+ 49. Kd3
comment:
I want to thank you for
sending in this game. Unlike many who send submissions, you sent a loss. This
is exactly the kind of game that an individual can get the most out of -- one
of his/her draws or losses. It can be humbling at times, and even difficult,
but by going over a loss, trying to find out what went wrong, and how to
improve, will reap great results. I myself did the same when I was a youth,
and by continually going over games that I lost/drew, I found out what I did
wrong, and resolved not to repeat them. I did go over wins as well to look for
improvements, but rarely did I learn as much. BTW, I have a feeling that if
the computer gives you a free queen again, it will be in trouble, because
you've learned from your mistakes! Keep up the good fight.
